metadata.title: Apply for a licence to control wild birds

email.responseTime: We aim to respond within 5 working days

draft.name: Apply for a licence to control wild birds

pages.title: What's your name?
Summary
What's your phone number?

Why are you applying for a licence?

components.name: YpVSBm
components.title: Why are you applying for a licence to control wild birds?
components.hint: Choose the licensable purpose that best fits your situation

pages.title: Causing a genuine risk to air safety

components.name: MWhmjr
components.title: Html
components.content:
You can use a licence when wild birds pose a genuine risk to air safety. This could include when birds regularly:

  • gather on or near runways or landing areas
  • fly across aircraft flight paths
  • behave in ways that could lead to a bird strike

components.name: HnVuHJ
components.title: Is the bird species you want to control causing a genuine risk to air safety?

pages.title: Which wild birds do  you want to control?

components.name: bNhVtH
components.title: which wild birds you want to control?
components.hint: Select all the species you want to control.

pages.title: Control birds at an airfield

components.name: asalNW
components.content:
If you are the manager, occupier, or owner of an airfield, you may be eligible to register for to control wild birds that pose a threat to air safety under the CL12 class licence (opens in a new tab) issued by Natural England.

This licence allows you to catch alive or kill these birds on or around your airfield.

You can only act under this licence to control certain bird species within the designated distances from the airfield that are listed in the conditions of the CL12 class licence.

You must read the terms and conditions of the CL12 class licence to ensure you can meet all the requirements and it covers your circumstances.

You will need to complete this form and apply for an individual licence if:

  • the bird species you need to control is not listed for your airfield or within the specified distance
  • you are not the manager of an airfield or required to manage birds for air safety under planning controls
  • there is a protected site designated for birds on or within 300 metres of the airfield or the location where you plan to use the licence
  • you cannot meet any other of the licence conditions

components.name: XaySzm
components.title: Does the CL12 class licence cover your circumstances?

pages.title: What's the name of the species you want to control?

options.customValidationMessage: Enter the name of the species you want to control

pages.title: What species do you need to conserve?

components.name: OpPiON

options.customValidationMessage: Enter the species you want to conserve

components.title: What species do you want to conserve?
components.hint: List the species of wild bird, animal, plant or vegetation you need to conserve

pages.title: Recognised conservation concern

components.name: pZPBAb
components.content:
You can use a licence to control wild birds to conserve wild birds, animal or plants of recognised conservation concern. This means the species you want to conserve is :

  • a wild bird included in the British Trust for Ornithology (BTO) red or amber list (opens in new tab)
  • an animal, plant or vegetation is included in the Joint Nature Conservation Committee’s (JNCC) red list of Great Britain species (opens in new tab)

Natural England would not usually grant a licence to control a species of birds unless it was of lower or equal conservation concern than the species you want to conserve.

components.name: KIqaOS
components.title: Is the species you need to conserve of recognised concern?

pages.title: Alternative methods to conserve another bird, animal, plant or vegetation

components.name: yAlYyt
components.content:
To apply for a licence, you must provide evidence that either:

  • you have tried alternative non-lethal methods to control the wild birds
  • you can show that non-lethal methods would not be effective or practical

Examples of alternative methods include:

  • habitat management to maintain favourable conditions for species you want to conserve
  • providing cover or refuges for the animals you want to conserve
  • scaring measures such as shooting to scare and handheld lasers can be effective in certain situations, but use caution to avoid disturbing other vulnerable species
  • wider conservation measures you're taking to reduce the impact of other detrimental factors, which are also adversely affecting the species or habitat you need to conserve

Read about the non-lethal methods you can use to deter certain wild birds without a licence (opens in a new tab).

components.name: UKFUoY
components.title: Can you provide evidence that non-lethal alternatives were or would be ineffective alone in resolving the situation?

pages.title: Preserving public health and safety

components.name: qclnUs
components.content:
You must be able to provide evidence that shows the birds you want to control are either:

  • causing a risk to public health and safety
  • likely to cause a risk to public health and safety
T

Examples of the evidence you could provide include:

  • risks vulnerable groups like children, the elderly, or people with physical and mental health problems or disabilities
  • is a disease risk through contamination of foodstuffs or medical equipment
  • causes injuries, near misses or a high risk of harm
  • causes serious health and safety risks that regular building maintenance cannot fix, such as roof damage leading to water leaks and mould
  • increases other serious risks that you cannot mitigate
  • causes damage that needs urgent work to preserve public health and safety that cannot wait until the birds leave

components.name: FlhmvM
components.title: Do the wild birds pose a serious risk to public health and safety?

pages.title: Alternative methods to preserve public health and safety

components.name: HusevL
components.content:
To apply for a licence, you must provide evidence that either:

  • you have tried alternative non-lethal methods to control the wild birds
  • you can show that non-lethal methods would not be effective or practical

Examples of alternative methods include:

  • prevent access to food by avoiding outdoor eating, secureing food waste, and providing covered areas for people eat in
  • protect people and property by providing appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE), identify alternative routes, and implement safety measures for working at heights
  • manage environmental impact by conducting regular maintenance, installing gutter guards
  • consider long-term solutions such as regular works should be scheduled to avoid breeding season

Read about the non-lethal methods you can use to deter certain wild birds without a licence (opens in a new tab).

components.name: gRaPsR
components.title: Can you provide evidence that non-lethal alternatives were ineffective alone in resolving the situation?

pages.title: Preventing serious damage

components.name: WUBXPe
components.content:
To apply for an individual licence to prevent serious damage, the damage caused by wild birds must be more serious than a public nuisance or minor damage.

Serious damage

This means that the damage caused could result in serious financial harm to your organisation. Your organisation could not absorb it as part of its normal operations.

Minor damage or public nuisance

If the damage caused by the wild birds is minor (your organisation could absorb it as part of its normal operations) or it is a public nuisance, Natural England recommends you use alternative non-lethal methods to control the birds.

It is unlikely that Natural England would grant a licence in such cases unless you could provide evidence that damage could seriously risk public health and safety.

pages.title: Alternative methods to prevent serious damage

components.name: fghRzW
components.content:
To apply for a licence, you must provide evidence that either:

  • you have tried alternative non-lethal methods to control the wild birds
  • you can show that non-lethal methods would not be effective or practical

Examples of alternative methods include:

  • managing surrounding habitat to reduce suitability for the species you propose to control
  • using management strategies to reduce the risk of damage such as enclosed feeding options

Evidence of legal, non-lethal measures must show if they have been taken in the previous year and which methods you will use alongside any licensed action should also be provided.

Read about the non-lethal methods you can use to deter certain wild birds without a licence (opens in a new tab).

components.name: HYPnzA
components.title: Can you provide evidence that non-lethal alternatives were ineffective alone in resolving the situation?

pages.title: Based on your answers, you may not  be eligible for a licence

components.name: CeCXOn
components.title: Html
components.content: Based on the responses you have provided, Natural England believe it is highly unlikely that we would grant a licence for your situation if you were to continue with your application.

components.name: qGLdFU
components.title: Html
components.content: Your responses suggest that the wild birds you are concerned about are more of a public nuisance or inconvenience rather than posing a significant threat to public health or safety.

components.name: duAPdn
components.title: Html
components.content:
You cannot provide evidence that the species you want to control is causing or likely to cause a risk to public health or safety. For example:

  • evidence on the specific risk to public health and safety
  • who or what is at risk and why it's more than a nuisance or inconvenience
  • how the species' behaviour causes this risk
  • evidence of a pattern of this behaviour over time

components.name: EFyNke
components.title: Html
components.content: As you would not be able to provide sufficient evidence that shows the species you want to control poses a genuine risk of spreading disease to livestock or their feed.

components.name: SGiLHw
components.title: Html
components.content: Your responses indicate that the wild birds could cause only minor damage or be a public nuisance, which could be absorbed as part of your normal business risk. This damage is unlikely to pose a significant financial threat to your organisation.

components.name: YZEfjo
components.title: Html
components.content:
As you are unable to provide sufficient evidence that the species you want to control is causing or likely to cause serious damage. For example:

  • evidence on the extent of the damage and why it's more than minor
  • evidence that the damage presents a risk to your business's economic interest
  • evidence of the species' behaviour causing this risk
  • evidence of a pattern of damage over time

components.name: hquMtx
components.title: Html
components.content: As you are unable to provide sufficient evidence that the species is particularly vulnerable at the site where it exists.

components.name: AbJbLZ
components.title: Html
components.content:
As you cannot provide evidence that the species you need to control is affecting the species you want to conserve. For example:

  • nesting statistics or other verifiable records
  • observations of predation events recorded in a diary
  • results of monitoring by local wildlife groups or other third-party records

components.name: njzpbt
components.title: Html
components.content: Natural England would recommend trying to use alternative non-lethal methods to help manage wild birds you want to control. Read our managing wild birds (opens in new tab) guidance.

pages.title: Based on your answers you may not be eligible to apply for a licence

components.name: lDtstI
components.title: Html
components.content:
You may not be eligible to apply for a licence to kill, take or disturb wild birds because you cannot provide evidence:

  • you have tried non-lethal solutions, or you can show that they would not be effective or practical
  • there are no suitable alternative methods of control

components.name: EqmVCN
components.title: Html
components.content:
We would recommend trying to use alternative non-lethal methods to help manage wild birds you want to control.

Read about the non-lethal methods you can use to deter certain wild birds without a licence (opens in new tab) .

pages.title: Particularly vulnerable at the site

components.name: bMyAwr
components.content:
If the birds you want to conserve is not a recognised conservation concern or a feature of a protected site in unfavourable condition. To be able to apply for a licence you must be able to show that the species you want to conserve is particularly vulnerable at the site where it exists.

You will need to provide evidence of its vulnerability, for example, a report from an experienced ecologist who has assessed the importance, condition, and vulnerability of both the species to be conserved and the species to be controlled.

components.name: xCkjFc
components.title: Is the species you want to conserve vulnerable at the site where it exists?

pages.title: Impact on species you want to conserve

components.name: tMxIOm
components.title: Html
components.content:
You must be able to provide evidence of the negative impact the birds you want to control are having on the species you're trying to conserve. This evidence should:

  • show that is more than just one-off attacks
  • demonstrate a pattern over time
  • prove that the species you want to control poses a direct risk to the species you want to conserve

The evidence could include:

  • nesting statistics
  • observations in a diary format
  • results of monitoring by local wildlife groups

components.name: lCMdcn
components.title: Can you provide evidence that the species you need to control is impacting the species to conserve?

pages.title: Protected site

components.name: SECEam
components.title: Html
components.content:
You must tell us if the licensable activity you want to carry out is within or near to a protected site.

Use Defra Magic Maps to find out if your land is on a protected site,by:

  1. Visit the Defra Magic Maps website (opens in a new tab).
  2. In the search bar located in the left corner of the website, enter your postcode, grid reference, or coordinates.
  3. Click the search button.
  4. The map will zoom in on your location. Any protected sites in the area will be highlighted as coloured, hatched areas with labels. If nothing is displayed, it means your land is likely not on a protected site.
  5. Click on the 'i' identify tool in the toolbar at the top of the screen to find out the name of the protected site by clicking on the map with the appearing crosshair.

components.name: azPepW
components.title: Will the proposed activity be near or within a protected site?

pages.title: Feature of a protected site

components.name: kUWhmk
components.title: Html
components.content:
If the species you want to conserve is not on either the Joint Nature Conservation Committee's (JNCC) or British Trust for Ornithology's (BTO) lists, it will still be a recognised conservation concern if it is a feature of a protected site that is in an ‘unfavourable condition’.

You can use the Designated site website (opens in a new tab) to find out whether the species you want to conserve is a feature of a protected site:

  1. Enter the site name in the 'site name' text box.
  2. Click the search button.
  3. Click the 'View Details' link.
  4. The information you find will differ depending on the type of protected site:
    • Special Protection Areas (SPAs): Features are listed under the 'Designated Features' heading (SPAs are specifically for bird species)
    • Ramsar wetland sites: Designated features are listed under the 'Designated Features' heading
    • Sites of Special Scientific Interest (SSSIs): Click on 'Condition of SSSI Features and Units'
    • Special Areas of Conservation (SACs): A quick list of features is displayed. To see their condition, click 'View monitored features on units' under the 'feature on units' header (Birds will not be a feature of SACs, as they focus on non-bird features)

components.name: kocHSF
components.title: Is the species a feature of a protected site in unfavourable condition?

pages.title: What's the name of the protected site?
Alternative methods to prevent the spread of disease

components.name: sqstfM
components.title: Html
components.content:
To apply for a licence, you must provide evidence that either:

  • you have tried alternative non-lethal methods to control the wild birds
  • you can show that non-lethal methods would not be effective or practical

Examples of alternative methods include:

  • modify the site to discourage the wild birds, causing the problem from roosting or nesting 
  • using physical barriers or deterrents to prevent birds from accessing specific areas
  • scaring measures such as shooting to scare, handheld lasers or using gas gun used to deter the birds

Read about the non-lethal methods you can use to deter certain wild birds without a licence. (opens in new tab).

components.name: ToCNSv
components.title: Can you provide evidence that non-lethal alternatives were ineffective alone in resolving the situation?

pages.title: Alternative methods to deal with a risk to air safety

components.name: xunmZO
components.title: Html
components.content:
To apply for a licence, you must provide evidence that either:

  • you have tried alternative non-lethal methods to control the wild birds
  • you can show that non-lethal methods would not be effective or practical

Examples of alternative methods include:

  • scaring the birds using rope bangers, bird scaring rockets, distress calls, shooting to scare or human and vehicle disturbance
  • managing surrounding habitat to reduce suitability for the species you propose to control
  • physical proofing buildings if birds are roosting or nesting at the site, as well as netting or spiking to prevent them from doing so

Read the Civil Aviation Authority's (CAA) 'Wildlife hazard management at aerodromes (opens in a new tab) guidance on non-lethal methods you could use to preserve air safety.

components.name: CRkSIc
components.title: Can you provide evidence that non-lethal alternatives were ineffective alone in resolving the situation?

pages.title: Risk to public health and safety

components.name: UVvKfS
components.title: Html
components.content:
You must be able to provide evidence that shows the birds you want to control are either:

  • causing a risk to public health and safety
  • likely to cause a risk to public health and safety

The evidence should include:

  • accident, incident, and near-miss logs (with the personal or sensitive information redacted)
  • engineers or other relevant professionals' reports where problems relate to technical, structural, or electrical risks

If this type of evidence is not available or relevant to your situation, Natural England may also consider:

  • statements, diaries, complaints, repair or maintenance receipts or invoices, or other records that show how often risks occur and how serious they are
  • photographs or videos that demonstrate the risk

components.name: vOWPJl
components.title: Can you provide evidence of the birds' impact on public health and safety?

pages.title: Risk of serious damage

components.name: kZYxAa
components.title: Html
components.content:
You must be able to provide evidence that birds you want to control is causing or likely to cause serious damage to:

  • livestock
  • animal feed
  • crops
  • growing timber
  • fisheries

The evidence could include:

  • photos or videos of the damage
  • records or diary observations (such as predation events, numbers of livestock or the extent of crops damaged)
  • financial records showing the losses incurred
  • observations on the size of local bird flock and it's behaviour

components.name: INmvDF
components.title: Can you provide evidence that the species you want to control is causing or is likely to cause serious damage?

pages.title: Risk of the spread of disease

components.name: dVojBB
components.title: Html
components.content:
You must be able to provide evidence that shows that there is risk of the wild birds spreading a disease directly or through:

  • livestock
  • animal feed
  • crops
  • fisheries

The evidence could include:

  • positive test results showing disease-causing bacteria or viruses in livestock, feed or other areas that is linked to the wild bird species
  • photos or videos that show the risk of the disease spreading
  • advice from qualified professionals such as your vet
  • data on the birds population size and their behaviour relevant to disease transmission

components.name: EsyVxA
components.title: Can you provide evidence of the risk of a disease being spread?

pages.title: Do you want to control the wild birds to prevent the spread of an infectious avian disease to other birds?

components.name: SRXvYQ
components.title: Do you want to control the wild birds to prevent the spread of an infectious avian disease to other birds?'
components.hint: For example, Avian Influenza, Newcastle disease, and West Nile virus in wild birds

pages.title: Based on your response you may not be eligible to apply for a licence

components.name: qYKBwz
components.title: Html
components.content:
Natural England will not approve a licence to prevent of widespread avian diseases such as Avian Influenza, Newcastle disease, and West Nile virus to other birds.

Find out how to prevent and spot the spread of Bird Flu (Avian Influenza) .

If you suspect any type of avian influenza in poultry or captive birds, you must report it immediately by calling the Defra Rural Services helpline on 03000 200 301.

If you suspect any type of avian influenza in wild birds, you must report it using the report dead wild birds service (opens in a new tab) or call the Defra helpline on 03459 335 577.

pages.title: Protected sites

components.name: lNrJqT
components.title: Html
components.content:
You must tell us if the licensable activity you want to carry out is on or within 300 metres of a protected site.

Protected sites are areas of land or sea that are designated for the conservation of wildlife, habitats, or geological features.

Protected sites in England include:

  • Sites of Special Scientific Interest (SSSIs)
  • Special Areas of Conservation (SACs)
  • Special Protection Areas (SPAs)
  • Ramsar wetland sites

Use Defra Magic Maps to find out if your land is on a protected site:

  1. Visit the Defra Magic Maps website (opens in a new tab).
  2. In the search bar in the left corner of the website, enter your postcode, grid reference, or coordinates.
  3. Click the search button.
  4. The map will zoom in on your location. Any protected sites in the area will be highlighted as coloured, hatched areas with labels. If nothing is displayed, it means your land is not on a protected site.
  5. Use the 'i' identify tool on the toolbar to discover the name of the protected site. Click on the map with the appearing crosshair to get the information.
  6. If you are close to, but not on a protected site, click the measure tool (with the ruler icon) on the toolbar, then select the 'distance' icon (a ruler with 2 arrows above it).
  7. Click on the edge of the location where you intend to control birds that is closest to the protected site, then double-click on the nearest boundary of the protected site to gain a measure of the distance.

components.name: NHysPc
components.title: Will the proposed activity be within 300 metres or more of a protected site?

pages.title: What do you need to conserve?

components.name: qgQsNf
components.title: What do you want to conserve?

pages.title: Do you need to trap and release birds from a food premises?

components.name: QXqhEw
components.title: Do you need to trap or realise birds from a food premises?
components.hint: Food premises refer to enclosed areas used for the sale, production, processing, packaging, or storage of food intended for human consumption

pages.title: Control birds on a food premises

components.name: tHAbbf
components.title: Html
components.content:
As a food business owner or manager of a food premises, you may be able to register to use a CL03 class licence (opens in a new tab).

This license allows you to safely capture and release birds that have become trapped inside your premises.

You can only register registering to use the CL03 for the specific bird species listed on the licence. You must read and follow all the terms and conditions before using it.

You will need to complete this form and apply for an individual licence if:

  • the bird species is not listed on the CL03 licence
  • the premises is not a food premises
  • the bird has an active nest or eggs inside the premises
  • you want to kill the bird instead of trapping and releasing it
  • you cannot meet any other CL03 condition's

components.name: XyIxIP
components.title: Does the CL03 class licence cover your circumstances?

pages.title: Register for a CL03 class licence

components.name: aKAYIl
components.title: Html
components.content:
You should register for a class licence instead of applying for an individual licence. The CL03 class licence (opens in a new tab) allows you to remove birds trapped in food premises to protect public health or safety.

If you're still unsure if the CL03 licence covers your circumstances, you can contact the Natural England Bird Licensing team, by:

  • email at: bird.licensing@naturalengland.org.uk
  • calling: 0208 026 1089

pages.title: Register for a CL12 class licence

components.name: OseDqZ
components.title: Html
components.content:
You should register to use a class licence instead of applying for a individual licence.The CL12 class licence (opens in a new tab) allows you to kill or take wild birds to preserve air safety.

If you're still unsure if the CL12 licence covers your circumstances, you can contact the Natural England Bird Licensing team, by:

  • email at: bird.licensing@naturalengland.org.uk
  • calling: 0208 026 1089

items.text: Prevent the spread of disease directly or through livestock, animal feed, crops or fisheries

items.description: This includes preventing the spread of diseases to humans, either directly or through food contamination

items.text: Conserve wild birds, animals, or plants that are of recognised concern
